ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: High upconversion optical gain of Er3+-doped tellurite glass

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The upconversion technique of rare-earth-doped glasses or crystals is a potential route for achieving short-wavelength lasers (SWLs). The optical gain is an important parameter for evaluating lasing medium performance. Therefore, upconversion luminescence in glass with composition of 70TeO2–9PbF2–10AlF3–10BaF2–1Er2O3 was demonstrated, and the small-signal optical gain was measured via an amplified spontaneous emission technique when the sample was excited with a 980 nm laser. It was found that the optical gain was as large as 4.0 dB/cm, thus indicating that this glass may be a good medium for SWLs.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Short-wavelength lasers (SWLs) have wide applications in high-density optical storage, laser-induced nuclear fusion, laser projection television, laser radar and so on [1–5]. The short wavelength lasing output can be obtained from harmonic generators [6], semiconductor lasers [7, 8], optical parametric amplifiers [9], noble-gas lasers [10], excimer lasers [11] and upconversion lasers based on rare-earth-doped optical fibers or crystals [12, 13]. Amongst these lasers, the upconversion fiber lasers have many advantages such as solid-state lasing media, compact and portable structures, excellent mechanical performance and so on. Therefore, the upconversion lasers are still attracting much attention and, as a key component of upconversion lasers, the rare-earth-ion-doped upconversion glasses win more concerns [14].

Among all the rare-earth ions, Er3+ is frequently employed as an upconversion luminescence center due to its more homogeneous energy level array, enabling longer lifetimes of metastable energy levels. In the short-wavelength region, Er3+ can emit blue (4F7/2→4I15/2, 488 nm), green (2H11/2/4S3/2→4I15/2, 520/550 nm) and red (4F9/2→4I15/2, 660 nm) [15, 16], and the upconversion emissions of all these wavelengths have been observed when pumped with various wavelengths matching 2H11/2/4S3/2, 4F9/2, 4I9/2, 4I11/2 and 4I13/2 levels [16–20]. The upconversion luminescence of rare-earth ions is also dependent on the host material. Many host materials such as fluorides, halides, sulfides and oxides have been widely studied [17, 21, 22], and it was found that the rare- earth-ion-doped fluorides, halides and sulfides exhibit high upconversion luminescence efficiencies but preparative difficulty and weak stability in comparison with rare-earth-ion-doped oxides. Amongst all oxide hosts, the tellurite glasses with low phonon energy, excellent mechanical strength and high upconversion luminescence efficiency are preferable; thus, the upconversion luminescence behaviors of Er3+-doped tellurite glasses have been widely studied [15, 16, 20]. However, most of the present investigations on the Er3+-doped tellurite glasses are focused on the spectroscopic properties, upconversion mechanisms and laser devices [23, 24]; the optical gain properties of Er3+-doped glasses are rarely reported.

In this letter, the upconversion luminescence of Er3+ in tellurite glass was examined upon 980 nm excitation, and the optical gain for the green upconversion luminescence was measured via an amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) technique. A high optical gain was obtained to be 4.0 dB/cm, which indicates that the Er3+-doped tellurite glass may be an excellent medium for green upconversion lasers.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: The studied glass sample was prepared in air atmosphere by using a facile melt-quenching technique; the detailed preparative procedure can be found elsewhere in our previous work [15, 16]. The glass composition is 70TeO2–9PbF2–10AlF3–10BaF2–1Er2O3. The obtained glass was well polished and cut into about 2-mm-thick flakes. The upconversion emission spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrometer by using a 980 nm laser diode (LD) with 1 W light output as excitation source.

The optical gain was measured via an ASE technique, which has been successfully used in the studies of laser media [25, 26]. It is known that in an optical gain medium, when the excitation length increases, the stimulated emission intensity would increase along the direction of the increasing excitation length. The ASE technique for measuring optical gain is to use the relationship between the intensity of amplified spontaneous emission and the excitation length to evaluate the amplification ability of the laser gain medium. The gain measurement was also carried out on the same fluorescence spectrometer (Hitachi F-4500); a special setup shown in Fig. 1 was used. In Fig. 1, Roman number 1 represents the 980 nm LD excitation light beam with homogeneous energy density; component 2 is a diaphragm whose length for passing the excitation beam can be accurately adjusted with an uncertainty of ±0.01 mm, the height being constant; the excitation light beam with various lengths irradiates vertically on the large surface of the sample 3. The diaphragm is parallel to the large surface of the sample; the distance between the sample and the diaphragm is around 1 cm. With this diaphragm the excitation length can be changed but the height of the excitation beam is fixed. The signal of the ASE was collected from the side end of the sample via another diaphragm with fixed light-permeation area.
Fig. 1
Setup for measuring optical gain. 1—excitation laser beam; 2—excitation length adjustable diaphragm; 3—sample

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 2 shows the upconversion emission spectra for the Er3+-doped tellurite glass measured under 980 nm excitation; the excitation energy density, which is defined as the laser output power per unit area, was changed from about 18 to 40 W/cm2. In the measurements, the excitation energy density was changed by adjusting the working current of the laser diode and keeping the area of the laser beam spot unchanged. The blue (4F7/2→4I15/2), green (2H11/2/4S3/2→4I15/2) and red (4F9/2→4I15/2) upconversion emissions were observed when the sample was excited by the 980 nm LD with various excitation energy densities; the intensity of each emission increases with the increase of the excitation energy density. Amongst all the emissions, the green emission is most intense.
Fig. 2
Upconversion spectra for Er3+-doped tellurite glass under irradiation by 980 nm laser diode working at different currents

In order to explore the upconversion luminescence mechanism of the studied Er3+-doped tellurite glass, the relationships between the laser diode working current and the integrated upconversion luminescence intensity for the blue, green and red emissions were derived from the upconversion emission spectra and are shown in Fig. 3a–c as dotted curves. It is seen that the upconversion emission intensities increase nonlinearly with increasing working current of the laser diode. It should be mentioned that the working current for the green upconversion emission is limited to be smaller than 600 mA, since the upconversion emission intensity at higher working current of the laser diode exceeds the measuring limit of the spectrometer. It is known that the dependence of the upconversion luminescence intensity I on the working current i of the laser diode can be expressed mathematically as follows [27–29]: 1
$$ I = a(i - i_{0})^{n}, $$ where n represents the depleted 980 nm photon number for generating just one upconversion emitting photon; i 0 is the threshold current of the laser diode and a is a constant. Equation (1) was obtained on the basis of the fact that the output power of the 980 nm LD is linearly dependent on the LD working current. The relationship between the output power and the LD working current is shown in Fig. 3b as an inset. By fitting Eq. (1) to the experimental data in Fig. 3, the n values for blue, green and red upconversion emissions were confirmed, respectively, to be 1.82, 2.08 and 1.95 with reasonable uncertainties as labeled in Fig. 3. All n values are close to the theoretical value of 2 for the double-photon process, indicating that the two-photon upconversion processes are responsible for these tricolor emissions in Er3+-doped tellurite glass under 980 nm excitation. The possible upconversion mechanisms for these upconversion processes have been widely investigated [16–20], and we will not repeat the discussion here.
Fig. 3
Blue, green and red upconversion luminescence intensity dependence on the laser diode working current

By using the setup described in Fig. 1, the upconversion emission spectra were measured when changing the excitation length (namely, the light-passed length of diaphragm 2). The excitation energy density was estimated to be 25 W/cm2. The excitation length can be adjusted with the setup in Fig. 1 within micrometer scale; thus, the small-signal optical gain can be obtained. Moreover, the sample thickness is small, so that the spontaneous emission can be amplified in a nearly straight line path. Under these conditions, assume that the net small-signal optical gain coefficient at wavelength λ is g, and the total radiation intensity detected by the spectrometer is I(Δl) including the stimulated emission intensityΔIand the spontaneous emission intensity I(Δl)−ΔI. Based on the definition of the optical gain coefficient, for the excitation length Δl it can be derived that 2
$$ \Delta I = gI(\Delta l)\Delta l. $$ Under the small-signal condition, the ASE intensity can also be written as 3
$$ \Delta I = I_{\mathrm{s}}DT\Delta l\exp (g\Delta l) - I_{\mathrm{s}}DT\Delta l, $$ where T and D are thickness of the sample and the width of the laser beam, respectively. I s is the excitation intensity per unit volume. The first item, DTΔl, on the right of the above equation is the volume element within the total radiation intensity, in which both the spontaneous irradiation intensity and the stimulated emission intensity are involved; the second item is the spontaneous emission intensity. Combining Eqs. (2) and (3), it can be obtained that 4
$$ I(\Delta l) = \frac{I_{\mathrm{s}}A}{g}\bigl[\exp (g\Delta l) - 1\bigr], $$ where A=DT. Equation (4) presents the relationship between the total emission intensity I(Δl) and the excitation length in a laser medium with net optical gain coefficient of g.

The square dots in Fig. 4 show the dependence of the upconversion emission intensity at the central wavelength of 545 nm for the 4S3/2→4I15/2 transition on the excitation length in single- logarithmic coordinates. Equation (4) was used to fit the experimental data in Fig. 4; the net optical gain coefficient was derived to be 2.5 cm−1, which is equal to 4.0 dB/cm. The optical gain properties for rare-earth-doped optical fibers and waveguides were widely studied in the downconversion processes [30–36], but rarely reported for the upconversion processes [37–39]. Table 1 shows the optical gains for different transitions of rare-earth ions in various hosts. It can be concluded from Table 1 that the obtained optical gains for the f–f transitions of rare-earth ions in the inorganic media are extremely smaller than those of semiconductor materials (∼103 dB/cm) and laser dyes (∼102 dB/cm) [40] due to the smaller stimulated-emission cross sections of f–f transitions. In addition, the optical gain depends also on the pumping route, the radiative transition process, the host type and so on. In Table 1 the optical gains for f–f transitions in various hosts cover a broad range from ∼10−2 to several dB/cm and, amongst these hosts, the present Er3+-doped tellurite glass exhibits higher optical gain than the others, thus indicating that it may be a good laser medium for achieving a SWL under a 980 nm pump.
Fig. 4
Dependence of 545 nm emission intensity on the excitation length

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: The upconversion luminescence in Er3+-doped tellurite glass was observed, and the dependence of the upconversion luminescence intensity on the laser diode working current of the pump source indicated that two-photon processes are responsible for the blue, green and red emissions. Importantly, the optical gain for the 4S3/2→4I15/2 transition of Er3+ was obtained under 980 nm excitation via an ASE technique. A large gain up to 4.0 dB/cm was obtained, thus indicating that this glass material may be a good host candidate for SWLs.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgements
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: This work was partially supported by NSFC (National Natural Science Foundation of China, Grant nos. 51002041, 51272109, 11104023, 11104024, 11274057 and 11374044), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (Grant nos. 3132013317 and 3132013100), the Natural Science Foundation of Liaoning Province (Grant nos. 20111031, 20111032 and 201202019), the Natural Science Foundation of Zhejiang Province (Grant no. R4100364) and the State Key Development Program for Basic Research of China (973 Program, Grant no. 2012CB626801).
